awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Multidisciplinary Computational Solutions to Smart Sensors and Sensing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This award renews an exemplary Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site on smart sensors and sensing systems at Michigan State University (MSU).  The RET Site will continue to develop a strong partnership between MSU and schools in the greater Lansing/mid-Michigan area to advance pre-college science and engineering education by training a cadre of leaders of middle and high school teachers in the areas of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). The RET site will expose teachers to leading engineering and computing research spanning biological and chemical sensors, robotics sensors, human-computer interaction, microelectronic sensing circuitry and networks, energy and automotive engines, high performance computing for nuclear science, and sensing materials and manufacturing techniques, and will connect them to the profound changes that sensors and sensing technologies are having on the daily lives and the quality of life of all citizens. The interdisciplinary nature of the research theme will provide a fertile ground for developing creative and appealing middle and high school lessons and teaching activities in biology, physics, chemistry, and technology that align with state and national curricular standards. 

The RET Site will expose teachers to cutting-edge research that has significant impact on the world today. Goals for this program are to train high-quality teachers that can inspire and prepare students for future college studies and careers in STEM fields, to improve teachers' skills in curriculum development, leadership, communication, and instruction, to implement and disseminate innovative curricula to connect university research activities to K-12 classroom practices, and to strengthen, sustain, and expand a long-term, healthy partnership between MSU, local school districts, and industry on advancing pre-college science and engineering education. Participating teachers will attend a 6-week summer institute to engage in cutting-edge research projects with mentoring from engineering faculty who lead vibrant sensor and sensing related research programs. Working with researchers, faculty mentors, and a curriculum development specialist, teachers will develop innovative, standards-compliant curriculum modules and participate in a number of professional development activities. The teacher-created modules and lessons will be disseminated nationally through TeachEngineering.org, a nationally recognized repository for searchable, standards-based engineering curricula.   Extensive follow-up activities are planned throughout the academic year to ensure the translation of lab experience into classroom practice, and to foster and strengthen long-term partnership between engineering faculty and the local school districts. A third-party professional program evaluator will track and evaluate the program and provide feedback for improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site

por.por_cntn:
The NSF RET Site on Multidisciplinary Computational Solutions to Smart Sensors and Sensing Systems is dedicated to providing authentic research experiences for middle and high school teachers. The program enhances educators' skills in curriculum development, leadership, communication, and instruction. It also supports the implementation and dissemination of innovative curricula that bridge university research with K-12 classroom practices, while fostering a sustainable, long-term partnership between Michigan State University (MSU) and local school districts.

Since its launch in 2019, the Site has supported 28 STEM teachers from across Michigan, with 50% being female and minority participants. Teachers were recruited from high-needs and rural schools across the state, including Lansing's community college. The program's core component is a six-week Summer Institute, supplemented by follow-up activities throughout the academic year.

During the Summer Institute, participants engaged in cutting-edge research, with "one-on-one" mentoring by MSU faculty who lead vibrant research programs. Teachers also developed standards-aligned, research-based curriculum and hands-on activities modules and participated in numerous professional development activities. Follow-up academic year activities helped ensure the successful integration of research experiences into classroom instruction. These activities also strengthened faculty-teacher collaborations and supported broad dissemination of outcomes through platforms such as TeachEngineering.org, the K-12 Design Day workshop, and invited talk. A third-party evaluator assessed the program through periodic surveys, on-site observations, and interviews, providing valuable insights for ongoing improvement.

Overall, the RET Site has had a substantial impact on K-12 STEM education through teacher professional development and curriculum innovation. Since 2019, RET participants have created 33 curriculum units including lessons and/or hands-on activities based on their research. Of these, 18 activities and lessons have been published on TeachEngineering.org (see the Table below). These contributions have significantly enriched STEM learning experiences for middle and high school students in Michigan and beyond. In addition, the program has helped inspire and prepare high school students for future college studies and careers in STEM fields. The strength and effectiveness of the RET Site are further evidenced by positive program assessments, with all participating teachers reporting high levels of satisfaction across multiple dimensions of the experience.

It also supports the implementation and dissemination of innovative curricula that bridge university research with K-12 classroom practices, while fostering a sustainable, long-term partnership between Michigan State University (MSU) and local school districts.

Teachers were recruited from high-needs and rural schools across the state, including Lansing's community college. The program's core component is a six-week Summer Institute, supplemented by follow-up activities throughout the academic year.


During the Summer Institute, participants engaged in cutting-edge research, with "one-on-one" mentoring by MSU faculty who lead vibrant research programs. Teachers also developed standards-aligned, research-based curriculum and hands-on activities modules and participated in numerous professional development activities. Follow-up academic year activities helped ensure the successful integration of research experiences into classroom instruction.
